columns.text: In this problem, we will solve for the initial cost of the investment while considering the flotation cost and retained earnings.

Before we start solving for the numerical values, we must first define the important concepts found in this problem.

**Flotation cost** refers to the costs involved when the company issues new stocks. These costs come from legal fees, registration fees, and all other underwritten fees related to issuing securities to the public.

**Retained earnings** refer to how much of the revenue is left after the company issues the dividends to its stockholders.

For this problem, the following values are given:
|Debt-Equity Ratio |0.65 | 
|--|--| 
|Cost |$51,000,000 | 
| New Equity Flotation Cost|7\% | 
| New Debt Flotation Cost| 2.7\%|

**a.)** For this, we will assume that all equity is raised externally. This means that the portion of the initial cost that is funded through equity, was earned by issuing new equity. This means that we will take that portion an multiply it by the flotation cost of equity since everything was raised externally.

In order to solve the cost of the project, we will first determine how much of the company is funded through and funded through debt. To do this, we will take the debt-equity ratio of $0.65$ and add $1$ to it which will represent the equity.

To get the weight of the debt, we will take the debt-equity ratio and divide it to $1.65$:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Weight of debt}&=\dfrac{0.65}{1.65}\\[15 pt]
&=0.394
\end{aligned}$$

To get the weight of equity, we will simply take the weight of debt and subtract it from $1$.

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Weight of equity}&=1-0.394\\[15 pt]
&=0.606
\end{aligned}$$

From the given weights above, we can now solve for how much of the initial cost of $\$51,000,000$ was from debt and how much was from equities. 

To solve for how much of the initial cost was funded by debt, we can take the initial cost and multiply it by the weight of debt.

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Initial cost funded by debt}&=\$51,000,000 \times 0.394\\[15 pt]
&=\$20,094,000
\end{aligned}$$

The initial cost that is funded by debt os $\$20,094,000$

To get how much of the initial cost was funded by equity, we will simply subtract the initial cost funded from the total initial cost.

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Initial cost funded by equity}&=\$51,000,000-\$20,094,000\\[15 pt]
&=\$30,906,000
\end{aligned}$$

The initial cost funded by equity is $\$30,906,000$

Now that we have the portion of the initial cost funded by both equity and debt, we can solve for the flotation costs. To do this, we will simply multiply the values in Step 4, by their respective flotation rates. The flotation rate for debt is given at $0.027$ while the flotation rate for equity is given at $0.07$.

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Flotation cost for debt}&=\$20,094,000 \times 0.027\\
&=\$542,538\\[15 pt]

\text{Flotation cost for equity}&=\$30,906,000 \times 0.07\\
&=\$2,163,420
\end{aligned}$$

The flotation costs for debt and equity are $\$542,538$ and $\$2,163,420$, respectively.

We can now solve for the first part of the problem by adding both the flotation costs and the initial cost.

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Total initial cost}&=\$51,000,000+\$542,538+\$2,163,420\\[15 pt]
&=\$53,705,958
\end{aligned}$$

The total initial cost for this case is $\$53,705,958$

**b.)** If the company uses $60\%$ retained earnings, then that means, $60\%$ of the portion funded through equity, came from the retained earnings. This means that the other $40\%$ is raised externally.

We can solve for how much equity was raised externally by taking the value of the equity in Step 5, and multiplying it to $40\%$ which is the portion that is funded externally.

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Equity funded externally}&=\$30,906,000 \times 0.40\\[15 pt]
&=\$12,362,400
\end{aligned}$$

This means that $\$12,362,400$ was raised externally.

We can then take the value above and multiply it to the flotation cost of equity.

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Flotation cost of equity}&=\$12,362,400 \times 0.07\\[15 pt]
&=\$865,368
\end{aligned}$$

The new flotation cost of equity is $\$865,368$

We can then solve for the total initial cost by taking the initial cost of $\$51,000,000$ and adding it to the flotation cost of debt and the new flotation cost of equity solved in Step 9.

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Total initial cost}&=\$51,000,000+\$542,538+\$865,368\\[`15 pt]
&=\$52,407,906
\end{aligned}$$

The total initial cost in this case is $\$52,407,906$

**c.)** For this final case, since all equity is financed through retained earnings, this means that there will be no flotation cost for equity. 

We can then solve for the total initial cost by adding the initial cost of $\$51,000,000$ and the flotation cost of equity which is $\$542,538$

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Total initial cost}&=\$51,000,000+\$542,538\\[15 pt]
&=\$51,542,538
\end{aligned}$$

The total initial cost, if all equity is taken from retained earnings, is $\$51,542,538$
